An '''environmental profit and loss account''' ('''E P&L''') is a company's monetary valuation and analysis of its [[environmental impact]]s including its [[business operations]] and its [[supply chain]] from [[Life-cycle assessment#Cradle-to-gate|cradle-to-gate]]. An E P&L internalizes externalities and monetizes the cost of business to nature by accounting for the [[ecosystem services]] a business depends on to operate in addition to the cost of direct and indirect negative impacts on the environment. The primary purpose of an E P&L is to allow managers and stakeholders to see the magnitude of these impacts and where in the supply chain they occur.
The E P&L analysis provides a metric to measure and monitor the footprint of the company's operations and suppliers all the way to the initial raw materials. It is a tool to build awareness of the importance of nature to the sustainability of businesses; enhance visibility across a company's supply chain and deepen understanding to focus sustainability efforts and implement better-informed operational decisions; improve specificity for risk management regarding environmental dependencies and impacts; and support a more [[holistic view]] of a company's performance, while bringing clarity and transparency to stakeholders at all levels and identifying new opportunities to enhance the sustainability of a company's products.
== Background == Conceived by PUMA Chairman, [[Jochen Zeitz]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2011/11/18/puma-jochen-zeitz-environment-footprint_n_1101126.html|title=Puma Reveals Its £124m Ecological Footprint|date=19 November 2011|publisher=}}</ref> and launched by Sportlifestyle company PUMA and its parent company's sustainability initiative (PPR HOME), the first-ever<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/puma-value-environmental-impact-biodiversity|title=Puma world's first major company to put a value on its environmental impact|first=Jo|last=Confino|date=16 May 2011|website=the Guardian}}</ref> E P&L was conducted on 2010 data and released in two phases. In May 2011 the valuation of PUMA's 2010 [[Greenhouse Gas]] Emissions (GHG) and water usage was announced,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-13410397|title=Puma reveals environmental impact|first=Richard|last=Anderson|date=16 May 2011|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> followed in November 2011, by PUMA's overall E P&L,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-15756080|title=Puma costs environmental impact|date=16 November 2011|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> which also included valuation results for other forms of [[air pollution]], [[land conversion]] and waste.
Simultaneously, the PPR Group announced in November 2011 that a Group E P&L would be implemented across its Luxury and Sport & Lifestyle brands by 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenbiz.com/blog/2011/11/18/gucci-ysl-follow-puma-revealing-environmental-impact-costs|title=Gucci, YSL to Follow Puma in Revealing Environmental Impact Costs|first=Leslie|last=Guevarra|date=18 November 2011|publisher=}}</ref>
== Methodology == The E P&L and the associated methodology were developed with the support of [[PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP]] and [[Trucost]] PLC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.just-style.com/analysis/supply-chain-weighs-on-pumas-first-green-accounts_id111097.aspx|title=Supply chain weighs on Puma's first green accounts|date=17 May 2011|publisher=}}</ref> The E P&L used existing input-output models and developed new valuation methodologies, building on a large volume of work in the fields of environmental and natural resource economics such as [[TEEB]], the UN study on [[The Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity]].
Kering, the parent company for Puma, has released its Environmental Profit and Loss Accounting methodology in an open source mode.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csrwire.com/press_releases/37967-Kering-Open-Sources-Environmental-Profit-and-Loss-Account-Methodology-to-Catalyse-Corporate-Natural-Capital-Accounting|accessdate=13 August 2016|title=Kering Open-Sources Environmental Profit and Loss Account Methodology to Catalyse Corporate Natural Capital Accounting|date=May 19, 2015|author=Kering|via=CSRWire}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kering.com/sites/default/files/document/kering_epandl_methodology_and_group_results.pdf|accessdate=13 August 2016|title=Kering Environmental Profit & Loss}}</ref> [[Novo Nordisk]] is another company that has released its environmental profit and loss account<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.mst.dk/Udgiv/publications/2014/02/978-87-93178-02-1.pdf|accessdate=13 August 2016|title=Novo Nordisk’s environmental profit and loss account|year=2014}}</ref> and methodology report.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.mst.dk/Udgiv/publications/2014/02/978-87-93178-03-8.pdf|accessdate=13 August 2016|title=Methodology report for Novo Nordisk’s environmental profit and loss account|year=2014}}</ref> The 2017 annual report of Philips mentioned that the company had an environmental impact of Euro 7.2 billion for that year. This assessment was made through an Environmental Profit and Loss Accounting process. The company mentioned that this monetary value has not considered various practices that has environmental impacts.<ref>https://www.philips.com/c-dam/corporate/about-philips/sustainability/downloads/ecovision-methodologies/EPL-Account-methodology-2017.pdf</ref>
== Engagement == The UK government used the PUMA E P&L as a case study for sustainable business in the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affair ([[DEFRA]]) Natural Environment White Paper in June 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journalofaccountancy.com/Web/20114243.htm|title=U.K. Government White Paper Calls for Tracking Green Losses, Gains|date=22 June 2011|publisher=}}</ref> In July 2011, [[Pavan Sukhdev]] who was the Study Leader of TEEB and the Special Advisor and Head of UNEP's Green Economy Initiative, referred to the PUMA E P&L in his TED presentation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ted.com/talks/pavan_sukhdev_what_s_the_price_of_nature.html|title=Put a value on nature!|publisher=}}</ref> Sustainability authority, [[John Elkington (business author)|John Elkington]] includes the PUMA E P&L in his "The Future Quotient: 50 Stars in Seriously Long-Term Innovation".<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111042028/http://www.thecro.com/content/future-quotient|title=The Future Quotient|work=CR Magazine|archivedate=11 January 2012|publisher=|url=http://www.thecro.com/content/future-quotient|author=John Elkington|author2=Charmian Love|author3=Alastair Morton}}</ref> In the October issue of ''[[The Harvard Business Review]]'' the PUMA E P&L is included in "The Sustainable Economy" by [[Yvon Chouinard]], Jib Ellison, and Rick Ridgeway.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.peoplesgrocery.org/fmd/files/Sustainable%20Economy%20HBR%20Oct%202011.pdf | title=The Sustainable Economy | work=The Harvard Business Review | date=October 2011 | author1=Yvon Chouinard|author2=Jib Ellison|author3=Rick Ridgeway | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111112041748/http://www.peoplesgrocery.org/fmd/files/Sustainable%20Economy%20HBR%20Oct%202011.pdf | archivedate=2011-11-12}}</ref> In the Winter 2012 issue, the ''[[Stanford Social Innovation Review]]'' published "Connecting Heart to Head" by Ram Nidumolu, [[Kevin Kramer]], & Jochen Zeitz. The PUMA E P&L is included as a business case study.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ssireview.org/articles/entry/connecting_heart_to_head|title=Connecting Heart to Head (SSIR)|publisher=}}</ref> In December 2011, Jochen Zeitz spoke at His Royal Highness The Prince of Wales' Accounting For Sustainability Forum about the PUMA E P &L.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mPFVIv-32G8|title=Jochen Zeitz, CEO Sport and Lifestyle Group, CSO of PPR and Chairman of the Board of PUMA|first=|last=ThePrincesA4S|date=21 December 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
Puma's EP&L accounting process has influenced other companies attempting natural capital accounting <ref>https://naturalcapitalcoalition.org/connecting-finance-and-natural-capital-case-study-for-eftec-natural-capital-statements/</ref>. A smartphone app has been made available, free of cost, to help students of design and fashion, to understand the environmental impacts<ref>https://naturalcapitalcoalition.org/kering-and-parsons-school-of-design-develop-free-epl-app-for-fashion-students/</ref>.
== Critique == An assessment report indicated that preparing an EP&L report can be expensive, while benefits being derived from the process is substantial.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bsl-lausanne.ch/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/AssesofPotLimitationsValuExFinal-Report.pdf | title=Assessment of potentials and limitations in valuation of externalities | date=2014 | isbn=978-87-93178-33-5}}</ref> EP&L Accounting has also been considered as a first step in the process of ensuring that prices reflect the use of environmental goods and services.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://cmsdata.iucn.org/downloads/ep_l.pdf | title=The Case for Environmental Profit and Loss Accounting | publisher=IUCN | author=Nathalie Olsen Head}}</ref>

{{infobox ethnic group |group = Filipinos in Kuwait |image= |population = '''180,000'''
(2012)
 |popplace = |langs = [[Languages of the Philippines]], [[English language|English]] and [[Arabic]] |rels = [[Roman Catholicism]] or other [[Christian denomination]]s, [[Islam]] |related = [[Filipino people]], [[Overseas Filipinos]] }} '''Filipinos in Kuwait''' are either migrants from or descendants of the [[Philippines]] living in [[Kuwait]]. As of 2012, there are roughly 180,000 of these Filipinos in Kuwait. Most people in the Filipino community are migrant workers,[http://globalnation.inquirer.net/news/breakingnews/view_article.php?article_id=68858 Kuwait grants amnesty to illegal aliens] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209230026/http://globalnation.inquirer.net/news/breakingnews/view_article.php?article_id=68858 |date=2012-02-09 }} and approximately 60% of Filipinos in Kuwait are employed as [[domestic worker]]s. ==Overseas employment== In 2016, Kuwait was the sixth-largest destination of [[Overseas Filipino]] workers, with 90,000 hired or rehired in the nation in 2011, and accordingly Kuwait has been an important source of [[remittance]]s back to the Philippines, with over $105 million [[United States dollar|USD]] being remitted in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.gov.ph/publications/AG%202012-04%20-%20OFW.pdf|title=Overseas Filipino Workers At A Glance|date=May 2012|publisher=[[Senate of the Philippines]]|accessdate=6 January 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kcic-asia.com/UserFiles/file/KCIC%20%20Weekly%20Analysis%20-%20May%2030%202010.pdf|title=Philippine Remittances Rising Despite Declines from Kuwait and Hong Kong|last=Zhang|first=Thomas|year=2010|publisher=Kuwait China Investment Company|accessdate=6 January 2013}} Nine Filipino banks have [[correspondent account]]s with banks in Kuwait to allow for remittance transfers.{{cite web|url=http://www.smc.org.ph/MAPID/MAPID%20CD/Italy%20pdf%20file/012.III.3%20ANNEX%201%20Philippine%20Banks%20with%20Remittance%20Network%20Abroad.pdf|title=Philippine Banks With Remittance Networks Abroad|publisher=Scalabrini Migration Center|pages=5|accessdate=6 January 2013}} There is a Filipino Worker's Resource Center (FWRC) located in [[Jabriya]], and it provides refuge for Filipino workers in Kuwait who have "[experienced] various forms of maltreatment from their employers such as fatigue, non-payment of salaries,"{{cite news|url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/184406/reftab/96/t/Seventy-distressed-HSWs-repatriated-to-Philippines/Default.aspx|title=Seventy Distressed HSWs Repatriated To Philippines|date=12 June 2012|publisher=Arab Times|accessdate=5 January 2013}} as well as "lack of food [and] physical, verbal and sexual abuse".{{cite news|url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/170034/reftab/96/t/131-distressed-Pinoys-fly-home-to-Philippines/Default.aspx|title=131 Distressed Pinoys Fly Home To Philippines|date=7 June 2012|publisher=Arab Times|accessdate=5 January 2013}} Through assistance from the FWRC, the Philippine Embassy in Kuwait, the [[Philippine Overseas Employment Administration]], and Overseas Workers' Welfare Administration, hundreds of Filipinos in Kuwait have been repatriated to the Philippines due to these issues.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/274878/pinoyabroad/news/dfa-31-ofws-repatriated-from-kuwait-400-more-to-come-home-soon|title=DFA: 31 OFWs repatriated from Kuwait, 400 more to come home soon|date=20 September 2012|publisher=GMA News|accessdate=5 January 2013}} Filipino domestic servants in Kuwait are the most expensive overseas servants that can be hired, due to a minimum wage requirement by the Filipino government as well as high costs from recruitment agencies.{{cite news|url=http://www.kuwaittimes.net/read_news.php?newsid=NTY1MjYxNTUzOQ|title=Cost of hiring maids rises sharply|last=Fattahova|first=Nawara|date=7 September 2011|publisher=Kuwait Times|accessdate=6 January 2013}} Minimum monthly wage of a Filipino maid is [[Kuwaiti dinar|KWD]] 110 per month ($365 USD), with an initial recruitment cost of KWD 850 ($2825 USD), with the price varying based on previous experience. ==Society and culture== Kuwait had the largest number of voters registered under the [[Overseas Absentee Voting Act]] eligible to vote in the [[Philippine general election, 2013|2013 Philippine general election]].{{cite news|url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/182646/reftab/96/t/Kuwait-Filipinos-top-OAV-globally/Default.aspx|title=Kuwait Filipinos Top OAV Globally|date=1 May 2012|publisher=Arab Times|accessdate=5 January 2013}} Philippine holidays such as [[Independence Day (Philippines)|Independence Day]], commemorating the [[Philippine Declaration of Independence]], are celebrated in Kuwait.{{cite news|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/global-filipino/06/12/12/pinoys-celebrate-independence-day-kuwait|title=Pinoys celebrate Independence Day in Kuwait|last=Santiago|first=Maxxy|date=12 June 2012|publisher=ABS-CBN News|accessdate=6 January 2013}} Religious events, such as the Catholic festivities honoring [[Our Lady of Peñafrancia]] as well as the Muslim holiday [[Eid al-Adha]] are celebrated by their respective Filipino Catholic and Filipino Muslim communities.{{cite news|url=http://www.voxbikol.com/bikolnews/1824/filipinos-kuwait-celebrate-pe%C3%B1afrancia|title=Filipinos in Kuwait to Celebrate Peñafrancia|last=Acuña|first=Melo|date=10 October 2009|publisher=Bikol News|accessdate=6 January 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ph/2012/11/07/filipino-muslim-community-in-kuwait-celebrates-eidl-adha-and-the-signing-of-the-bangsamoro-framework-agreement/|title=Filipino Muslim community in Kuwait celebrates Eid’l Adha and the signing of the Bangsamoro Framework Agreement|date=7 November 2012|publisher=Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs|accessdate=6 January 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.pinoysinkuwait.com Filipinos in Kuwait] {{Immigration to Kuwait}} {{Overseas Filipinos}} {{Demographics of Kuwait}} [[Category:Filipino diaspora by country|Kuwait]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Kuwait]] [[Category:Kuwait–Philippines relations]]

The '''Glasgow Magdalene Institution''' (Glasgow’s Magdalene Institution for the Repression of Vice and Rehabilitation of Penitent Females was its official name)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/books/a-magdalene-laundry-that-was-neither-irish-nor-catholic-and-novel-it-inspired-1.2526837|title=A Magdalene laundry that was neither Irish nor Catholic, and novel it inspired|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-03-16|language=en-US}}</ref> was an asylum in [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]], initially started in 1812 and was open until it closed in 1958.
The institution was started in response to the increasing worries of prostitution, the spread of venereal diseases and wavering moral values seen in the country, and sought to "rescue" women or girls who were deemed "[[Prostitution|prostitutes]]" and teach them how to support themselves through industrial training mainly through the laundries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image/?inum=TGSG00036|title=TheGlasgowStory: Glasgow Magdalene Institution|last=ABACUS|first=Scott Graham -|website=www.theglasgowstory.com|access-date=2017-01-27}}</ref>
== History of the Institution == With its establishment in 1812 it had originated on Parliamentary Road until it moved to [[Lochburn Home]] in 1864 where it remained until its closure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/books/a-magdalene-laundry-that-was-neither-irish-nor-catholic-and-novel-it-inspired-1.2526837|title=A Magdalene laundry that was neither Irish nor Catholic, and novel it inspired|website=The Irish Times|publisher=The Irish Times|last1=Talbot|first1=Theresa|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> It was non-denominational and was funded by voluntary subscriptions – as well as the income generated from being a working laundry.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/books/a-magdalene-laundry-that-was-neither-irish-nor-catholic-and-novel-it-inspired-1.2526837|title=A Magdalene laundry that was neither Irish nor Catholic, and novel it inspired|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-03-16|language=en-US}}</ref> The women in the asylum were generally termed as prostitutes, however, it should be noted that this term was used in a very loose manner encompassing not only women who sold sex for money but also single mothers, socialists, mill girls and girls dressed 'immorally'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://special.lib.gla.ac.uk/exhibns/month/nov2000.html|title=Magdalene Institution|website=special.lib.gla.ac.uk|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
In Glasgow, the Magdalene Asylum evolved into the Magdalene Institution with a new Glasgow System created to deal with court appearance of women who refused to be checked for venereal diseases by policemen. The Lock Hospital was set up in Rottenrow Lane in 1805 to treat women with venereal disease. Meanwhile, the Magdalene Institute took women who were free from syphilis, not pregnant, to be newly ‘fallen’ and willing to submit to discipline.
The Glasgow System, as it became known, saw unprecedented collusion between the local constabulary and the medical authorities. Women under suspicion could be forced to undergo an intimate examination by male police officers; if they showed signs of VD they would be incarcerated in the Lock Hospital without limit of time. Many were never released. The Glasgow system was deemed so successful it was adopted by several cities across Britain. The Lock Hospital didn’t close its doors until 1950.
The fifth annual report of the Magdalene Institute, written in 1864, said it was of “profound regret an of painful surprise” that the “resorts of profligacy should so much abound” in both Glasgow and Scotland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/scotland-s-magdalene-asylums-for-fallen-women-1-4382349|title=Scotland’s Magdalene Asylums for "fallen women"|website=www.scotsman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref> In Glasgow, wayward girls were placed at the Magdalene Institute by parents or probation officers until 1958.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/scotland-s-magdalene-asylums-for-fallen-women-1-4382349|title=Scotland’s Magdalene Asylums for "fallen women"|website=www.scotsman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
== Reactions Towards the Institution == Reactions to the Institution varied over time.
An advertisement in 1888 claimed: "nearly 5,000 young women have shared more or less in the benefits of the Institution since 1859. During the same period no fewer than 1,080 young women have been restored to parents or friends, and 942 have been placed in domestic service or other respectable employment, while thirty-two were sent abroad, thus making 2,054 who have been rescued from a life of shame and restored to society, after having received the usual education and training in the Homes".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image/?inum=TGSG00036|title=TheGlasgowStory: Glasgow Magdalene Institution|last=ABACUS|first=Scott Graham -|website=www.theglasgowstory.com|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
The Institution went unchecked until 1958 – when it was closed down – after the inmates staged a “riot” amid claims of abuse and ill treatment. The girls were all aged between 15 and 19 years of age and none had been convicted of a criminal offence. Despite this police all over the city were hunting for them and newspaper reports called on the public to be vigilant and look out for the girls, distinctive in their blue dresses and white aprons. Each time the girls were rounded up they staged another breakout, some escaping down the fire escape; others staged a rooftop protest. They vowed to keep escaping until their voices were heard. The “riot” lasted for three days. The final breakout occurred during a visit by officials from the Scottish home department who were investigating the series of events. There was an official inquiry into their claims of beatings, bullying and verbal abuse; as of March 2017 no one has been held accountable.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/books/a-magdalene-laundry-that-was-neither-irish-nor-catholic-and-novel-it-inspired-1.2526837|title=A Magdalene laundry that was neither Irish nor Catholic, and novel it inspired|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-03-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Other Magdalene Institutions in Scotland, and Beyond == At their height the [[Magdalene asylum|Magdalene Asylums]], which were run around the world, had 20 refuges in [[Scotland]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/scotland-s-magdalene-asylums-for-fallen-women-1-4382349|title=Scotland’s Magdalene Asylums for "fallen women"|website=www.scotsman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
The first in [[Edinburgh]] opened in 1797. In the capital, the charitable organisation, funded by church collections and private donations, opened in the Canongate in the Old Town, a popular location for street prostitutes. In the early 1800s, there were around 200 brothels in Edinburgh. The Magdalene Asylum was “sharply segregated place,” according to Scot-Pep, a sex worker’s rights organisation based in Edinburgh, with prostitutes kept away from those women of a “better order.” Women were kept in solitary confinement for the first three months “to eradicate the taint of moral contagion”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/scotland-s-magdalene-asylums-for-fallen-women-1-4382349|title=Scotland’s Magdalene Asylums for "fallen women"|website=www.scotsman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
One resident of the Edinburgh asylum, Mary Paterson, (originally from Glasgow) was murdered by [[Burke and Hare murders|Burke and Hare]] shortly after leaving the institution on 8 April 1828.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/scotland-s-magdalene-asylums-for-fallen-women-1-4382349|title=Scotland’s Magdalene Asylums for "fallen women"|website=www.scotsman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
In Ireland, the [[Magdalene asylum|Magdalene Asylums]], or Magdalene Laundries, were usually run by Roman Catholic orders and different to the Scottish system. A scandal broke in 1993 after a mass grave containing 155 corpses was found in the convent grounds of one of the laundries in [[Dublin]]. A formal state apology was issued in 2013 and a £50 million compensation scheme for survivors of abuse was set up.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/scotland-s-magdalene-asylums-for-fallen-women-1-4382349|title=Scotland’s Magdalene Asylums for "fallen women"|website=www.scotsman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
== The Glasgow Magdalene Institution and Popular Culture ==
The Glasgow Magdalene Institution has inspired popular culture through a novel like ''Penance'' by [[Theresa Talbot]] that was published in October 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.stridentpublishing.co.uk/book-review/penance/|title=Penance - stridentpublishing.co.uk|newspaper=stridentpublishing.co.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-27}}</ref> It is a crime fiction novel based on the Glasgow Magdalene Institution. Theresa Talbot was born and raised in Glasgow to Irish parents and has always had an awareness of the Magdalene Institution. Through initial research for a radio series with the [[BBC]], she began to develop the inspiration and story for her novel. She based the novel as a crime narrative through dramatic licenses to give the women of the Glasgow Magdalene Institution a voice.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/culture/books/a-magdalene-laundry-that-was-neither-irish-nor-catholic-and-novel-it-inspired-1.2526837|title=A Magdalene laundry that was neither Irish nor Catholic, and novel it inspired|newspaper=The Irish Times|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-27}}</ref>

The '''Guernsey Society''' is an organisation for people with an interest in the [[Bailiwick of Guernsey]].
==Society aims== The Guernsey Society aims are to promote, maintain and stimulate interest in all matters concerning the [[Bailiwick of Guernsey]], its past, present and future - and keeping alive the ''Spirit of Guernsey'' both in the islands and overseas. *Publish ''The Review of the Guernsey Society'' three times a year - a high quality magazine with articles on Guernsey's past, present and future *Organise meetings - both formal and informal - in [[Guernsey]], the [[United Kingdom]], and elsewhere *Provide a network for anyone with an interest in Guernsey<ref>Society Aims - [http://www.guernsey-society.org.uk Guernsey Society web site]</ref>
==History of the Society== The Guernsey Society was formed in 1943 to represent the interests of the island to the British Government during the [[German occupation of the Channel Islands|German Occupation]], and to establish a network for Guernsey evacuees in the United Kingdom.
The Society was the idea of three Guernseymen based in London: Sir [[Donald Banks]], Air Commodore Henry Le Marchant Brock and Colonel Guy Durand Ozanne. Banks became the first Chairman, and Brock became the first Secretary. Other notable founder members included: actor [[Barry Jones (actor)|Barry Jones]], Professor [[John Le Patourel]], [[William Arnold (Bailiff)|Sir William Arnold]] and Professor [[Herbert John Fleure|Herbert Fleure]].<ref>Brock, H Le M, ''Twenty One Years Ago'', Quarterly Review of the Guernsey Society, 1964</ref>
==Publications== The Society has published a regular magazine since 1945. ''The Bulletin'' appeared eight times during 1945 and 1946. It became ''Quarterly Review of the Guernsey Society'' in January 1947, and continued until 1971, when the frequency was reduced to three times a year, and the title changed to ''The Review of the Guernsey Society''. Since its inception it has published articles from a wide range of respected Guernsey figures including [[Ambrose Sherwill]], [[John Le Patourel]], [[James Marr (author)|James Marr]], [[Marie de Garis]] and [[TF Priaulx]].<ref>Foote, S, ''A Review of the Review'', Review of the Guernsey Society, Summer 2010</ref>
In the summer of 1944, the newly formed Society was instrumental in organising, together with prominent members of the Jersey Society in London, a symposium in Oxford to start planning for the future of the Channel Islands following their liberation from [[German occupation of the Channel Islands|Nazi Occupation]]. The result was the publication of a book, ''Nos Iles'', which was widely read by members of the [[States of Guernsey]] and [[States of Jersey]], and became known as "the Liberation Army's bible".<ref>Read, Brian Ahier, ''Jersey in London'', Seaflower Books, 1994</ref>
The Society has also published a number of books on the island and its history: *[[Ralph Durand|Durand, R]], ''Guernsey under German Rule'', 1946 - one of the first accounts to be published about life during the [[Occupation of the Channel Islands|German Occupation]] *[[Eagleston, AJ]], ''Channel Islands Under Tudor Government'', 1951 *Members of the Guernsey Society, ''The Guernsey Farmhouse'', 1963 - a survey of the architecture of Guernsey farmhouses *''Guernsey Ways'', 1966 - a selection of articles from the Review, published to celebrate the 900th anniversary of the [[Battle of Hastings]] *[[James Marr (author)|Marr, LJ]], ''More Guernsey People'', 1992 - the sequel to Marr's ''Guernsey People'' biographical dictionary (published 1984) * Johnston, Peter ''A Short History of Guernsey'', 2014.<ref>[http://www.guernsey-society.org.uk/?page_id=500 A Short History of Guernsey], retrieved 15 Oct 2015</ref> *[[Ralph Durand|Durand, R]], ''Guernsey under German Rule'', 2018 - the society published a new edition of this work, which had long been out of print, to mark the 75th Anniversary of the society. The new edition includes a Foreword by the Bailiff of Guernsey, [[Richard Collas|Sir Richard Collas]], and an introduction by Vice Chairman, Stephen Foote.<ref>[http://www.guernsey-society.org.uk/?page_id=927 Guernsey Under German Rule] - Guernsey Society website, retrieved 22 Nov 2018</ref>
== Notability == Articles from ''The Review'', as well as other Society publications, have been influential and widely used as source material for authoritative works on the island's history. Examples include: * ''The Guernsey Farmhouse'' provided the inspiration for John McCormack's ''The Guernsey House''.<ref>McCormack, John, ''The Guernsey House'', Phillimore, 1980</ref> * [[Marie de Garis]]' ''Folklore of Guernsey'' started off as a series of articles published in ''The Review'' during the 1970s.<ref>de Garis, Marie, ''Folklore of Guernsey'', La Société Guernesiaise, 1975</ref> * The following published doctoral theses cite a number of articles from ''The Review'' amongst their references: ** Stevens-Cox, Gregory, ''St Peter Port 1680-1830: the history of an international entrepot'', Boydell Press (1999) ** Crossan, Rose-Marie, ''Guernsey 1814-1914: Migration and Modernisation'', Boydell Press (2007) * Edward Chaney's series of articles (1994–95) about [[Gerald Basil Edwards|G B Edwards]], the reclusive author of [[The Book of Ebenezer Le Page]] formed the basis for the authoritative biography ''Genius Friend: G.B. Edwards and The Book of Ebenezer Le Page'', published by [http://www.blueormer.co.uk Blue Ormer Publishing] in 2015. * The official history of the [[Occupation of the Channel Islands]], commissioned by the governments of [[Guernsey]] and [[Jersey]] in 1970, lists among its references ''Nos Iles'' and Durand's ''Guernsey Under German Rule'' (see above).<ref>Cruickshank, Charles, ''The German Occupation of the Channel Islands'', Imperial War Museum (1975)</ref> * Eagleston's book ''The Tudor Administration of the Channel Islands'' is widely cited, and seen as the reference work for this period in the islands' history.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?cites=12014363537640191578&as_sdt=2005&sciodt=0,5&hl=en Google Scholar citations]</ref>
==Activities== The Society organises regular formal and informal meetings in London and Guernsey.<ref>Guernsey Society web site - [http://www.guernsey-society.org.uk/meetings.htm Meetings]</ref>
In 2010, the Society launched ''Donkipedia'', a wiki dedicated to the Bailiwick of Guernsey.<ref>[http://www.donkipedia.org/ Donkipedia]</ref>
==See also== * [[Archaeology of the Channel Islands]] * [[Jersey Heritage]] * [[Société Jersiaise]]
== References == {{Reflist|40em}}

[[Image:Kafna Village.jpg|thumb|300px|Kafna Village.]] The '''Irob people''' ([[Ge'ez alphabet|Ge'ez]]: ኢሮብ ''ʾirōb'', also spelled Erob) are an ethnic group who occupy a predominantly highland, mountainous area by the same name in northeastern [[Tigray Region]], Ethiopia. They speak the [[Saho language]]. The majority of them are [[Ethiopian Catholic Church|Ethiopian Catholic]], and they are largely agriculturalists. The etymology of the name Irob is debatable, but the elders of the Irob say that the term was derived from Saho word "Oroba", meaning "welcome to our house". The boundaries of Irobland are, to an extent, identical to the [[Irob (woreda)|Irob]] woreda; both are bordered by the following areas: Dabri-Mela to the north, Hado to the east, the [[Afar Region]] to the east and south, Shoumezana and [[Gulomahda|Gulomakeda]] to the west, and [[Saesi Tsaedaemba]] to the south. The first two neighbors are Saho speakers and predominantly Muslim, the third are Muslim Afars, and the others are Tigrigna-speaking Christians.
==History==
[[Image:Irob boys in Alitena.jpg|thumb|300px|Irob boys in Alitena.]] The capital (traditional center) of Irob is [[Alitena]]. Irobs trace their lineage to one man, Summe, son of Neguse Worede-Mehret, who according to the Irob oral history, migrated to the Irobland from Tsira'e in [[Kilite Awla'elo]], a part of Tigray, about 700 years ago.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}
Despite their relatively small population, the Irob have been at the forefront of regional and national politics in Ethiopia. Starting with the [[Zemene Mesafint]], the Irob family of [[Ethiopian aristocratic and court titles|Shum]] Agame Woldu dominated Tigrayan politics. The dynasty included [[Dejazmach]] [[Sabagadis|Subagadis]] (whose rule extended to present-day Eritrea), Shum Agame Desta, Ras [[Sebhat Aregawi]], and many others including Emperor [[Yohannes IV]].
During the Italian invasion, Irob patriots, led by individuals such as Dejazmach [[Ayele Sebhat]] and Dejazmach [[Kassa Sebhat]],<ref>Anthony Mockler recounts how they attacked, and almost destroyed, an Italian column that had advanced from southern Eritrea, across the [[Danakil Depression]], to reach the edge of the [[Ethiopian highlands]]. (''Haile Selassie's War'' [New York: Olive Branch Press, 2003], pp. 66f)</ref> contributed to the anti-Italian resistance movement from their base on [[Mount Asimba]].
In more recent times, many Irobs, such as Dr. [[Tesfay Debessay]], who was a leader of the [[Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Party]] (EPRP), played an important role in the struggle waged against the dictatorial junta led by Colonel [[Mengistu Haile Mariam]].
[[Image:Assimba mountain in the distance.jpg|thumb|300px|Assimba mountain from a distance.]][[Image:Aiga Village.JPG|thumb|300px|Aiga Village.]] Moreover, the Irobland proper, particularly around the Assimba and Aiga localities, served as a base for several Ethiopian revolutionary movements, including EPRP and the [[Tigray People's Liberation Front]](TPLF). Aiga is also the location of significant battles during the Ethio-Eritrean border war (1998–2000), which ultimately lead to the removal of occupying Eritrean forces from the region.
==Lifestyle and Culture==
The Irob are divided into three major subgroup,s or ''Are'' (Houses): Adgadi-Are, Buknaiti-Are and Hasaballa. The Adgadi-Are and Hasaballa are predominantly Orthodox Christians, while Bouknaiti-Are consist of Catholics.
The Irob economy is primarily based on agriculture, including animal husbandry. The region is also renowned for its excellent honey. In fact, the Miess /[[Tej]] or local "Beer"(honey-wine) made from the honey is praised throughout the region for its quality.
In general, the Irob are a bicultural community. With their Saho-speaking neighbors, they share a common language and certain social structures, such as a clan division system called ''Mela'', and the title ''Ona'' for their regional leaders. Many other cultural practices, including wedding ceremonies, dress, dance, and food; however, are more similar to their Tigrigna-speaking neighbors specially with the peoples of Agame.
Irobs also have distinctive customs. For example, they have an elaborate poetry-telling tradition called ''Adar''. The Irob men have a dance/step routine called ''Hora'' and ''Alkafo'', which was traditionally performed in preparation for battles and still commonly displayed during weddings and other ceremonies. [[Image:Addaga Village.jpg|thumb|300px|Addaga Village.]]
==References== <references/> {{Refimprove|date=January 2009}}

Nine South Korean nationals were recorded as living at [[Bethlehem]], and four at [[Ramallah]].</ref> |langs = [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Arabic]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] |rels = [[Buddhism]], [[Christianity]], [[Islam]] |related-c = [[Korean diaspora]] }}
'''Koreans in the Arab world''' used to form a major part of the worldwide [[Korean diaspora]]. [[Koreans]] started coming to the [[Arab world]] in large numbers in early 1970s as [[foreign worker|migrant labourers]]; between 1975 and 1985, 1.1 million Koreans came for work, which made it the third-most popular destination for Korean emigrants.<ref name="Seok">{{harvnb|Seok|1991|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=SVHnp2XSeioC&pg=PA56 56]–58}}</ref> Eventually, most returned home or moved on to other countries, and {{as of|2014|lc=on}}, the [[Government of South Korea|South Korean government]]'s own figures showed over 24 thousand of their nationals living in the region. However, [[South Korea]]n nationals are present in all of the region's countries, and [[North Korea]]n workers also have a growing presence in several of them.<ref name="MOFAT2011Overall"/>
==History== Though Korea had a long history of trading contact with the [[Arab world]] by means of intermediaries, there were no recorded Korean visitors before 1959, when two [[Islam in Korea|Korean Muslims]] went to [[Mecca]] for the [[hajj]].<ref name="Baker">{{harvnb|Baker|2006}}</ref> In 1974, the first South Korean firm won a contract in the region, for highway construction in Saudi Arabia, and imported 218 South Korean construction workers, the first Korean residents, to assist in the project. The following year, 3,593 South Koreans went to Saudi Arabia for work. By 1977, migrants to Saudi Arabia alone composed nearly one-fifth of all registered emigration from South Korea, making it the third-most popular destination for emigrants (the top two being [[Japan]] and the [[United States]], each of which had longstanding Korean communities, [[Korean Americans]] and [[Zainichi Korean]]s).<ref name="Bonacich">{{harvnb|Bonacich|Light|1991|pp=105–106}}</ref>
The growth in the South Korean migrant worker population reflected a deliberate policy of the government to promote manpower exports; they had established a special department for this purpose as early as the mid-1960s, and in the 1970s, construction enterprises were given priority in order to facilitate their entry into overseas markets.<ref>{{harvnb|Park|1998|pp=122–123}}</ref> Over two dozen [[list of South Korean companies|South Korean companies]] employed migrant labour, the largest such employer being [[Hyundai Construction]]; Koreans were described as having a "competitive advantage" over workers of other nationalities due to their discipline and level of skill, which some commentators attributed to South Korea's practise of universal male [[conscription]]. Unlike their Western competitors, Koreans worked around the clock in shifts; huge lighting systems were installed to facilitate night work.<ref name="Steers">{{harvnb|Steers|1999|pp=107–119}}</ref> A survey of migrants showed that 73% were between 25 and 40 years old; under half (48%) of the regular workers were married, while 69% of contract workers were.<ref>{{harvnb|Seok|1991|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=SVHnp2XSeioC&pg=58 58]–59}}</ref>
The receiving countries were concerned about the effect that long-term residence of migrant workers could have on their societies; they preferred Korean workers because they were unaccompanied by family members and so stayed only for short periods.<ref>{{harvnb|Park|1998|p=122}}</ref> The typical length of an assignment in the region was three years.<ref name="Steers"/> Migration to the region would peak in 1982 and 1983.<ref name="Seok"/> Wages were around four to five million won, roughly twice what could be earned in South Korea at the time, and workers typically remitted 80% of their salaries. Families used saved remittances to purchase houses or start businesses. However, migration was not a success for everyone: roughly one-in-ten workers returned from the Middle East reported a decrease in income, usually due to inability to find suitable work. The hot, dry climate and long work hours also resulted in health problems for many workers, and the medical bills whittled away at their savings.<ref>{{harvnb|Seok|Yang|1992|p=106}}</ref>
Several factors in the late 1980s contributed to decreasing the amount of Korean migration. Increasing labour unrest initiated by South Korean workers provided one stimulus for the localisation of the workforce.<ref name="Halliday"/> South Korea's rising labour costs were another reason. During the latter half of the 1980s, the proportion of Korean labourers working on construction projects for Hyundai declined from 70% to only 20-30% during the 1980s, with the shortfall being taken up by local labourers instead.<ref name="Seok"/><ref>{{harvnb|Kwon|O'Donnell|2001|pp=104–105}}</ref> By 1990, only 56,000 South Korean migrant workers went abroad to any destination, a drop of over 70% since 1982.<ref>{{harvnb|Park|1998|pp=121–122}}</ref> By 1992, the wage gap between South Korea and the rich countries of the Middle East had largely disappeared.<ref>{{harvnb|Seok|Yang|1992|p=111}}</ref> The South Korean population would shrink over the following decade before rebounding slightly to 13,008 by 2009. Over the next two years, the population would show rapid growth of nearly 27%, reaching 16,461 by 2011. Nearly three-quarters of that recent population growth was driven by increased migration to the [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref name="MOFAT2011Overall"/><ref name="MOFAT2009">{{harvnb|MOFAT|2009}}</ref>
Furthermore, in an echo of the South Korean policy of the 1970s and 1980s, the North Korean government has also been sending its workers abroad to earn hard currency for their country recently. {{As of|2009}}, there were estimated to be six thousand North Korean workers in various Arab countries, including Kuwait, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, and Yemen; like the South Koreans two decades earlier, they also work primarily in construction-related trades such as welding and carpentry.<ref name="ChosunIlbo20091225">{{citation|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2009/12/25/2009122500238.html|title=N. Korean Workers Brave Hard Times in UAE|periodical=Chosun Ilbo|date=2009-12-25|accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref>
==By country==
===Bahrain=== Bahrain was a minor destination for South Korean migrant workers in the late 1970s and early 1980s.<ref name="Seok"/> South Korea used to have an embassy in Bahrain from 1976 to 1999, but closed it in a round of cost-cutting measures after the [[1997 Asian financial crisis]]. However, South Korean companies continued to do business in various fields in Bahrain, including construction, heavy industry, power, [[desalination]] plants and [[electronic engineering]].<ref name="GDN20120206">{{citation|url=http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=323148|title=New education exchange plans are on the way|periodical=Gulf Daily News|date=2012-02-06|accessdate=2012-04-30}}</ref> In 2001, there were only about 70 South Koreans in Bahrain, primarily corporate assignees. However, the small population was enough to support a single Korean supermarket as well as a few Korean restaurants.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sf.koreatimes.com/article/54502|title=바레인 한인사회|work=Korea Times|date=2001-10-25|accessdate=2012-04-30}}</ref> As of 2011, South Korean consular statistics recorded 282 of their nationals living in Bahrain. Four had Bahraini nationality, while the other 278 were on temporary visas. Their population grew by about 15% since 2009. There were no [[international student]]s.<ref name="MOFAT2011Bahrain"/> However, in 2012, in 2012, Bahrain and South Korea signed an agreement on promoting [[study abroad]] exchanges between the two countries.<ref name="GDN20120206"/>
===Egypt=== {{See also|Demographics of Egypt}} Egypt was a relatively minor destination for Korean migrant workers.<ref name="Seok"/> The Cairo Korean School, founded on 5 December 1979, is one of the region's few Korean day schools; it enrolled 27 students at the elementary level {{As of|2007|lc=on}}.<ref>{{harvnb|NIIED|2007|loc=[https://web.archive.org/web/20040222172747/http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_formal_inform.htm?no=20&page=1&key= 카이로한국학교]}}</ref> However, their student numbers have been falling, and from 2002 until 2008 they did not even hold any graduation ceremony.<ref>{{citation|url=http://channel.pandora.tv/channel/video.ptv?ch_userid=yunhap&prgid=34441561|date=2009-02-20|accessdate=2009-09-19|periodical=Yonhap News|title=카이로 한국학교 8년만의 졸업식/Cairo Korean school holds first graduation ceremony in 8 years}}</ref> There is also a Korean church in Cairo, which conducts various outreach activities.<ref>{{citation|title=세계 속 한민족 : 이집트 한인 교회 여성 봉사대 가난한 집 아기 씻기고 분 발라줘/Koreans around the world: Egypt Korean church women's service team helps babies of low-income families|periodical=JoongAng Ilbo|date=2005-03-08|accessdate=2009-09-19|url=http://pdf.joins.com/article/article_view.asp?Total_ID=457266&PressDate=20050308&PressCategory=A&PressMyun=08}}</ref> {{As of|2011}}, South Korean consular statistics recorded 995 of their nationals or former nationals living in Egypt, with 886 in [[Cairo]] and surroundings, and 109 living in other parts of the country. 21 are [[Egyptian nationality law|Egyptian nationals]], 65 are [[international student]]s, and 909 have other kinds of visas. Their population has remained roughly stable since 2009.<ref name="MOFAT2011Egypt"/>
The [[Korean School in Cairo]] (카이로한국학교), a South Korean international school, is in [[New Cairo]].<!--https://web.archive.org/web/20061002014253/http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_formal_inform.htm?no=20&page=1&key=6--><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150801043954/http://cairoschool.kr/ Home]. [[Korean School in Cairo]] (카이로한국학교). August 1, 2015. Retrieved on September 21, 2015. "48 Rd 1st Zone 6th Area New Cairo, Egypt"</ref>
===Iraq=== {{See also|Demographics of Iraq}} The first group of nine South Korean workers arrived in [[Iraq]] in 1975; however, until the end of 1980, only a total of 1,958 registered emigrants went to the country. However, their numbers would increase along with the intensification of the [[Iran–Iraq War]]; from 1981 until 1985, Iraq was consistently the second to fourth-most popular Arab world destination for South Korean migrant labourers, a total of whom 66,665 went to the country during that period.<ref name="Seok"/> In March 2003, then-[[President of South Korea|president]] [[Roh Moo-hyun]] agreed to dispatch a contingent of [[Military of South Korea|ROK army engineers]] to Iraq.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.heritage.org/Research/AsiaandthePacific/wm427.cfm?renderforprint=1|title=South Korean Troops to Iraq: A Boost for U.S.-ROK Relations|last=Hwang|first=Balbina|periodical=Heritage Foundation WebMemo|date=2004-02-13|accessdate=2009-05-22|issue=427}}</ref> Later the South Koreans expanded their presence, creating an entirely new division, the [[Zaytun Division]], consisting of 3,600 troops; they were sent to Iraq in September 2004. As of March 2007, about 1,600 remained; another 400 were expected to return home in April, with the others departing by the end of the year.<ref>{{citation|last=Lee|first=Chi-dong|title=South Korean troops asked to stay longer in Iraq|periodical=Yonhap News|date=2007-03-13|accessdate=2007-04-26|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/Engnews/20070311/500100000020070311095547E0.html}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=South Koreans detained by Iraq insurgents released|periodical=People's Daily|date=2004-04-09|accessdate=2007-04-26|url=http://english.people.com.cn/200404/09/eng20040409_139879.shtml}}</ref> There were also 113 South Korean civilians in Iraq {{As of|2011|lc=on}}.<ref name="MOFAT2011Iraq"/> There are no registered schools for Korean nationals in Iraq.<ref name="NIIED 2007">{{harvnb|NIIED|2007}}</ref>
===Jordan=== {{See also|Demographics of Jordan}} [[Jordan]] was only a minor destination for South Korean migrant workers in the 1970s and 1980s. The first group of 90 migrant workers arrived in 1975; from then until 1985, a total of 12,544 came to the country. The number reached its peak with 2,404 in 1980 but fell to less than a quarter that level by 1985.<ref name="Seok"/> By 2011, the country had the Arab world's seventh-largest Korean population. From 356 in 2009, the number of South Korean nationals grew by 66% to 592 in 2011. Among them, 48 were international students, while 544 held other types of visas; none had become Jordanian nationals. The vast majority (556, or 94%) lived in [[Amman]] or its surroundings, with another 14 living at [[Irbid]], and 22 in other places.<ref name="MOFAT2011Jordan"/><ref name="MOFAT2009"/>
South Koreans in the country pursue a variety of professions. Some are interested in investing in construction projects in the country.<ref>{{citation|url=http://news.mk.co.kr/newsRead.php?sc=30000021&cm=%EC%A0%95%EC%B9%98%20%EC%A3%BC%EC%9A%94%EA%B8%B0%EC%82%AC&year=2009&no=42593&selFlag=&relatedcode=&wonNo=&sID=302|periodical=[[Maeil Business Newspaper]]|title=김의장, 요르단 교포 격려|date=2009-02-21|accessdate=2012-02-24}}</ref> The [[Korea International Cooperation Agency]] has been sending Korean language instructors to the [[University of Jordan]] and other universities in the country since 2002.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.dongponews.net/news/articleView.html?idxno=8703|periodical=Dongpo News|date=2006-09-26|accessdate=2012-02-25|title=요르단 국립대학 한국어과 개설|last=Jeong|first=Jae-su}}</ref> More controversially, some of the South Koreans in Jordan are missionaries. By 2004, there were estimated to be at least 30 South Korean Christian missionary families living in [[Amman]]. Many had previously lived in Iraq but left the country under pressure from the South Korean government; after their arrival in Jordan, they often worked with [[Iraqis in Jordan|Iraqi migrants and refugees in the country]] in an effort to convert them.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/01/international/asia/01missionaries.html?_r=1|title=Korean Missionaries Carrying Word to Hard-to-Sway Places|first=Norimitsu|last=Onishi|authorlink=Norimitsu Onishi|date=2004-11-01|accessdate=2012-02-25|periodical=The New York Times}}</ref> One well-known South Korean who grew up in Jordan and naturalised as a citizen there is [[Won Ho Chung]], an Arabic-speaking comedian who rose to fame in the region through the [[Axis of Evil Comedy Tour]] in 2007.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.arabnews.com/lifestyle/offbeat/article455379.ece|date=2011-06-15|accessdate=2012-02-25|first=Marriam|last=Mossalli|periodical=Arab News}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/10/world/middleeast/a-multicultural-comic-wows-arab-crowds-with-an-insiders-touch.html?pagewanted=1&_r=2&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&pagewanted=all|title=A Multicultural Comic Wows Arab Crowds With an Insider's Touch|first=Vinita|last=Bharadwaj|date=2012-05-09|accessdate=2012-05-10|periodical=The New York Times}}</ref>
===Kuwait=== {{See also|Demographics of Kuwait}} Koreans in [[Kuwait]] first arrived in 1975 as employees of [[List of South Korean companies|South Korean construction companies]], although the two countries did not establish formal relations until June 1979.<ref name="CheongwadaeKuwait">{{harvnb|Cheongwadae|2007|loc=[http://16cwd.pa.go.kr/cwd/en/pub/president/cnt0202010602.html President Roh Moo-hyn's State Visit to the State of Kuwait]}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|MacKellar|1982}}</ref> By this time, Kuwait had already become the second-most popular [[Middle East]]ern destination for Korean workers behind [[Saudi Arabia]]; by that time, 13,813 Korean workers had already come to Kuwait. However, Kuwait would soon lose the second-place position, being surpassed by [[Libya]] in 1981 and [[Iraq]] in 1982.<ref name="Seok"/><ref name="Bonacich"/> Koreans in Kuwait generally did not receive a welcome from or assimilate to the local society; in common with [[India]]ns, [[Filipino people|Filipinos]], and [[Pakistanis]], they were described as being at the bottom of the social structure, "ridiculed and stripped of their rights".<ref>{{harvnb|Mohammed|2003|p=21}}</ref> Nor did they spend much of their money locally; as meals and housing were provided for them in their work camps, it was estimated that they [[remittance|remitted]] 80% of their earnings back to South Korea.<ref>{{harvnb|Mohammed|2003|p=20}}</ref> In spite of these difficulties, between 1975 and 1985, 63,898 South Korean workers came to Kuwait, and as late as 1990, roughly 10,000 were estimated to remain.<ref name="Seok"/> Kuwait's only school for Korean nationals, the Kuwait Hangul School, was established in 1991.<ref>{{harvnb|NIIED|2007|loc=[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181746/http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_informal_inform.htm?no=699&page=1&key= 쿠웨이트한글학교]}}</ref> Most South Koreans returned home in the following decade, and {{As of|2011|lc=on}}, only 1,000 South Korean nationals resided in the country. There were no known former South Korean nationals with Kuwaiti nationality; six were international students, and the remainder had other kinds of visas.<ref name="MOFAT2011Kuwait"/>
There was formerly a small contingent of [[Military of South Korea|South Korean soldiers]] in Kuwait, who numbered 170.<ref name="CheongwadaeKuwait"/> South Korean civilian employees from the [[United States Army]]'s [[Camp Casey, South Korea|Camp Casey]] in [[Dongducheon]], [[Gyeonggi-do]] have been deployed to bases in Kuwait, including [[Camp Arifjan]], in support of the US Army.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.army.mil/article/50576/Casey_Exchange_employee_among_first_Koreans_to_serve_Soldiers_abroad/|title=Casey Exchange employee among first Koreans to serve soldiers abroad|last=Choi|first=Jin|date=2011-01-10|accessdate=2012-02-25|periodical=Army.mil}}</ref> In 2005, a group calling itself Kuwait Mujahideen claimed to have killed a Korean national as part of an attack on a US Army base in [[Umm Al-Hayman]] near [[Al Ahmadi, Kuwait|Al Ahmadi]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2517872|last=Suh|first=Jung-min|title=Seoul denies Korean soldier was killed in Kuwait|date=2005-01-16|accessdate=2012-02-25|periodical=JoongAng Ilbo}}</ref>
[[List of North Korean companies|North Korean companies]] have established a greater presence in Kuwait recent years, and the [[government of South Korea]] estimated that there are roughly three or four thousand [[North Korea]]n construction workers in the country {{As of|2004|lc=on}}.<ref name="CheongwadaeKuwait"/><ref>{{citation|title=About 3,000 North Korean Construction Workers in Kuwait: KOTRA|date=2004-11-27|accessdate=2009-05-22|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-5231876_ITM | periodical=YON - Yonhap News Agency of Korea}}</ref> [[Air Koryo]], the national airline of North Korea, began operating weekly flights between Pyongyang and Kuwait City in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nknews.org/2014/03/north-koreas-air-koryo-resumes-kuwait-city-flight/|first=Chad|last=O'Carroll|title=North Korea’s Air Koryo resumes Pyongyang–Kuwait service|work=NKNews.org|date=2014-03-27|accessdate=2014-10-01}}</ref>
===Libya=== {{See also|Demographics of Libya|Filipinos in Libya|Pakistanis in Libya}} Though [[Libya]] did not receive its first South Korean workers until 1977, it quickly became a popular destination; it was the only Arab country which experienced consistent growth in the number of Korean workers between 1981 and 1985, and by 1985 it had already become the Arab world's second most popular destination, with 23,138 arrivals from South Korea. In total, from 1977 until 1985, 103,953 South Koreans came to Libya.<ref name="Seok"/> However, virtually all returned home, and {{As of|2009|lc=on}}, it was estimated that only 854 South Korean nationals lived in the country.<ref name="MOFAT2009"/> The South Korean population fell a further 87% in the next two years, leaving just 111 South Koreans in the country.<ref name="MOFAT2011Libya"/> Libya also has a Korean weekend school, founded in 2000; it enrolled 22 students from kindergarten to high school levels {{As of|2007|lc=on}}.<ref>{{harvnb|NIIED|2007|loc=[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181531/http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_informal_inform.htm?no=686&page=2&key=6 재리비아주말한글학교]}}</ref>
North Korea also dispatched labourers to Libya in the 1980s and 1990s; a batch of Northern construction workers arrived in Libya in 2008. There were estimated to be roughly 200 North Korean expatriates in Libya {{as of|2011|lc=on}}.<ref>{{citation|url=http://nk.joins.com/news/view.asp?aid=4772139|periodical=[[JoongAng Ilbo]]|title=리비아 북한인 200명 왜 철수 안 시키나 {{bracket|Why the 200 North Koreans in Libya are not being evacuated}}|last=Yi|first=Yeong-jong|date=2011-02-25|accessdate=2011-02-26}}</ref> Among them are construction workers, doctors, and nurses. They were not evacuated during the [[2011 Libyan civil war|Libyan civil war]] that year. South Korean official media reported that Pyongyang had explicitly ordered their nationals in Libya and Egypt not to return home.<ref>{{citation|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2011/10/26/86/0401000000AEN20111026002200315F.HTML|periodical=[[Yonhap News]]|date=2011-10-26|accessdate=2011-10-30|title=N. Koreans in Libya banned from returning home}}</ref>
===Qatar=== {{See also|Demographics of Qatar}} South Korea and [[Qatar]] established diplomatic relations in 1974, and two years later, the South Korean embassy opened in [[Doha]].<ref name="CheongwadaeQatar">{{harvnb|Cheongwadae|2007|loc=[http://16cwd.pa.go.kr/cwd/en/pub/president/cnt0202010702.html President Roh Moo-hyun's Official Visit to the Qatar]}}</ref> [[Qatar]] was never a major destination for South Korean labourers; the first group of 636 workers did not arrive until 1976, and until 1985, only a total of 12,816 South Korean emigrants chose Qatar as their destination.<ref name="Seok"/> Unlike in other countries in the region, Korean workers in Qatar did not just come as employees of Korean companies, but also as subcontractors of [[List of Japanese companies|Japanese companies]] as well.<ref>{{harvnb|CFR|1980|p=28}}</ref> [[Qatar Airways]] is one of the major employers of South Koreans in Qatar.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/national/Detail.jsp?newsMLId=20111016000395|first=Hannah Stuart|last=Leach|date=2011-10-06|title=Competition high for 'flying girls'|periodical=Korea Herald|accessdate=2012-04-30}}</ref> {{As of|2011}}, South Korean consular statistics showed 2,184 of their nationals or former nationals living in the country, a decrease of 7.7% since 2009. 1,383 lived in [[Doha]], 467 in [[Mesaieed]], and 334 in [[Al Khor]]. Five were Qatari nationals, 112 were international students, and the remaining 2,067 had other types of visas.<ref name="MOFAT2011Qatar"/>
In addition, an estimated 3,000 North Koreans lived in the country {{as of|2015|lc=on}}.<ref name="peninsula1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/news/qatar/352293/around-3-000-north-koreans-in-qatar|title=Around 3,000 North Koreans in Qatar|publisher=The Peninsula Qatar|date=13 September 2015|accessdate=13 September 2015}}</ref> This accounted for approximately 40% of the working population of North Korean in the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Persian Gulf]] region at that time.<ref name="peninsula1"/> North Korean workers are reported to be among the lowest paid in the country, earning US$170/month, less than even [[Nepalis in Qatar|Nepali migrants]]; they perform low-skilled work such as [[plasterwork|plastering]] and [[brickwork|bricklaying]]. Their lives are subject to a great deal of official constraint, and they try to avoid contact with the South Koreans.<ref>{{citation|title=How's the Kimchi? Secret Lives of North Korean Workers Abroad|periodical=Radio Free Asia|date=2007-01-17|accessdate=2007-04-25|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/korea_migrants-20070117.html}}</ref> There were no registered schools for Korean nationals in Qatar {{as of|2007|lc=on}}.<ref name="NIIED 2007"/>
===Saudi Arabia=== {{See also|Demographics of Saudi Arabia|Filipinos in Saudi Arabia|Indonesians in Saudi Arabia|Turks in Saudi Arabia}} South Korea established [[diplomatic relations]] with [[Saudi Arabia]] in 1962, and opened an embassy in [[Jeddah]] in 1973, which would later move to [[Riyadh]].<ref name="CheongwadaeSaudi">{{harvnb|Cheongwadae|2007|loc=[http://16cwd.pa.go.kr/cwd/en/pub/president/cnt0202010502.html President Roh Moo-hyn's Official Visit to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia]}}</ref> Labour relations were especially a source of friction in Saudi Arabia; one eyewitness account by an American expatriate claims that Hyundai's management called in the [[Military of Saudi Arabia|Saudi military]] to put down a strike at the [[Jubail]] port construction project, and that the army then proceeded to arrest and execute several workers.<ref name="Halliday">{{harvnb|Halliday|1984}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Collins|2003|pp=100–101}}</ref> Korean workers were also not afforded the opportunity for much social contact with their host population, though a few did [[religious conversion|convert]] to Islam.<ref name="Baker"/> Migration to the country would peak in 1982 and 1983, with over 122,000 South Koreans entering Saudi Arabia in each of those years, making up over 70% of Korean migration to the region. However, by 1985, the number of South Koreans entering Saudi Arabia had fallen to 58,924, paralleling a downward trend in the whole region.<ref name="Seok"/> Saudi Arabia's first school for South Korean nationals was established in 1992 in [[Jeddah]]; {{As of|2007|lc=on}}, it enrolled a total of 23 children at the kindergarten level.<ref>{{harvnb|NIIED|2007|loc=[https://web.archive.org/web/20061002012148/http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_informal_inform.htm?no=690&page=3&key=6 젯다한국학교병설한글학교]}}</ref>
In 1998, South Korea closed their consulate in [[Jeddah]]. There was no known North Korean presence, and North Korea does not maintain diplomatic relations with the kingdom.<ref name="CheongwadaeSaudi"/> {{As of|2011}}, South Korean government figures showed 2,821 of their nationals or former nationals in the country, up by about 40% from 2,014 in 2011. This made them the second-largest Korean population in the region, having surpassed the population in Qatar which shrank during the same period. 43 were Saudi nationals, 65 were international students, and the remaining 2,713 had other kinds of visas. 1,479 lived in [[Damman]], 607 in [[Riyadh]], 394 in [[Jeddah]], 134 in [[Medina]], 100 in [[Jizan]], and 11 in [['Asir Province]].<ref name="MOFAT2011SaudiArabia">{{harvnb|MOFAT|2011|pp=272–273}}</ref><ref name="MOFAT2009"/>
There are two Korean international schools in Saudi Arabia: [[Korean International School of Jeddah]] (KISJ; 젯다한국국제학교<!--Other name: 젯다한국학교-->)<!--https://web.archive.org/web/20061002014242/http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_formal_inform.htm?no=18&page=1&key=6--> and [[Korean School in Riyadh]] (리야드한국학교).<!--https://web.archive.org/web/20061002014309/http://www.interedu.go.kr/edu_net/overseas/sch_formal_inform.htm?no=19&page=1&key=6--><ref>"[http://homepy.korean.net/~ksj/www/news/photo/read.htm?code=AS1316615750&num=205 Home]." [[Korean International School of Jeddah]] (젯다한국국제학교). Retrieved on September 21, 2015. "주소 : P.O.BOX 4322, Jeddah 21491, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia."</ref><ref>[http://cafe.naver.com/riyadhkoreanschool Home]. Riyadh Korean School. Retrieved on September 21, 2015.</ref>
===United Arab Emirates=== [[File:North Korean migrant worker numbers in Asia map.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Number of North Korean migrant workers in Asia]] {{see also|Expatriates in the United Arab Emirates}} The United Arab Emirates received a small contingent of Korean migrant workers in the late 1970s and early 1980s, but it was never a major destination.<ref name="Seok"/> However, due to rapid growth since 2005, the country has come to have the Arab world's largest Korean population.<ref name="MOFAT2011UAE"/> {{asof|2008}}, there were roughly 2,500 South Koreans living in [[Dubai]] alone, largely businessmen working at the 90 Korean companies which operated in the country.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticleNew.asp?section=theuae&xfile=data/theuae/2008/february/theuae_february897.xml|date=2008-02-26|accessdate=2009-05-22|title=South Korea to open consulate in Dubai|periodical=Khaleej Times}}</ref> Rapid population growth continued through 2011; by that year, South Korean consular statistics showed 5,665 of their nationals or former nationals living in the UAE, giving it the region's largest South Korean population, with more than twice as large a population as that in Saudi Arabia. Five were Emirati nationals, fourteen were international students, and the rest had other types of visas. 3,276 lived in [[Dubai]], 1,982 in [[Abu Dhabi]], 141 in [[Sharjah (emirate)|Sharjah]], 83 in [[Ajman]], 67 in [[Ras al-Khaimah]], 36 in [[Fujairah]], and 22 in [[Umm al-Quwain]].<ref name="MOFAT2011UAE"/>
Many South Koreans in the UAE are flight attendants working for [[Emirates Airlines]]; the number of Koreans working for Emirates Airlines increased from 15 in 1998 to 620 as of 2007, mostly based out of Dubai. Dubai has the UAE's largest community of South Koreans.<ref>{{citation|title=Korean Female Crew Capture Middle East|periodical=Chosun Ilbo|date=2007-05-04|accessdate=2007-05-04|url=http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200705/200705040012.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070510014534/http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200705/200705040012.html|archivedate=10 May 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, a consulate was not opened in Dubai until March 2008.<ref>{{citation|url=http://are-dubai.mofat.go.kr/eng/af/are-dubai/mission/about/index.jsp|title=About us|publisher=The Consulate General of the Republic of Korea in Dubai|accessdate=2009-05-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100405235607/http://are-dubai.mofat.go.kr/eng/af/are-dubai/mission/about/index.jsp|archivedate=5 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In Abu Dhabi, Reem Investments plans to develop a residential complex for South Korean expatriates on [[Al Reem Island]], and have engaged Gansam Architects of Seoul to design its {{convert|22,000|m2}} cultural centre.<ref>{{citation|first=Claire|last=Ferris-Lay|title=Reem Island inks construction deal with Koreans|work=Construction Week|date=2012-01-17|url=http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-15315-reem-island-inks-construction-deal-with-koreans/|accessdate=2012-08-22}}</ref>
There are also believed to be roughly 1,300 North Korean workers in the UAE, primarily in Dubai and [[Abu Dhabi]]. They earn between US$300 and $500 per month, but have to make so-called "loyalty payments" of $150 to $250 to the North Korean government. This has sparked discontent among the workers; in response, the North Korean government has sent security agents to patrol North Korean work camps and keep an eye out for people making critical comments.<ref name="ChosunIlbo20091225"/> In 2010, a branch of the Pyongyang [[Okryu Restaurant]] opened in Dubai, staffed by waitresses from North Korea; the restaurant earns hard currency to supplement the North Korean state budget.<ref>{{citation|url=https://www.npr.org/2010/12/31/132491605/dubai-restaurant-offers-a-taste-of-north-korea|first=Peter|last=Kenyon|title=Dubai Restaurant Offers A Taste of North Korea|date=2010-12-31|accessdate=2012-03-10}}</ref>
===Other countries===<!-- This section is linked from [[Koreans in Morocco]] --> Other countries which received Korean migrant workers in the late 1970s and early 1980s include [[Yemen]], [[Oman]], and [[Sudan]].<ref name="Seok"/> There are Korean weekend schools in [[Mauritania]] ([[Nouadhibou]]), [[Morocco]] ([[Rabat]] and [[Agadir]]) and [[Tunisia]] ([[Tunis]]).<ref name="NIIED 2007"/>

In the background can be seen three men: one with grey hair, one with long black hair and the last with a hat on. The man with grey hair is shown about to jump. There is also a woman in the background, with not much of her in focus, except that she is wearing purple ethnic clothing. | caption = American DVD cover | director = [[Tony Gatlif]] | producer = Tony Gatlif | writer = Tony Gatlif | starring = [[Marc Lavoine]]
[[Marie-Josée Croze]]
[[James Thiérrée]]
